segments.text: The tape doesn't ring on this tape recorder.
That's one of the things a rented recorder doesn't do.
I guess you were talking about people speaking loudly or not speaking loudly.
Some of us, that's just a question of where you are and what you're doing.
I can get up on the bridge of a ship and be heard at a distance, and so if it's necessary, I can do it.
It's like the people with whom I were associated with in the Army.
I could certainly hear what all the officers said to me without any problem, best I could tell.
You entered Berkeley in 37 in physics.
Right.
Okay.
Did you have any design towards oceanography when you enrolled at Berkeley?
Oh, I would say I didn't even know there was such a thing as oceanography at that stage in the game.
I learned fairly quickly, though, that there was.
I guess...
Within the first couple of years, I ran onto some books in the physics department.
I leaned towards physics, although that wasn't what I really started in at Berkeley, but nevertheless I got involved in the physics department at Berkeley fairly early on.
They had a nice little library and there were some oceanographic books there, but I really didn't have any
feeling that this was something in which one could make a living or anything of this kind.
In fact, it really was only barely that as I found out soon.
So I really didn't have any thought of that.
I was interested in the ocean and I, as I mentioned, was involved with the Naval ROTC at Berkeley at that period.
So I was interested in going to sea and working with the ocean, even though I was, in fact, really pushing toward a career as a physicist.
So you participate almost at once in the Naval ROTC, but I notice you don't really enter the Navy until June of 41.
Well, no, I was in Naval ROTC for the full four years at Berkeley, and I was commissioned
As a result of that, I had a Navy commission when I graduated in May of 1941 from Berkeley, and things were kind of beginning to slip over the brink toward war at that point in the United States.
practically everybody in my class in Naval ROTC was given orders to active duty within the first month or two after we graduated, even though the war hadn't, didn't start until December.
But several of us, a bunch of us, went off to Navy submarine school in New London, Connecticut.
And after that I went down
I had the privilege of being the first Naval Reserve Officer to stand one in a submarine school class, and he went off to the Philippines to join the submarine.
Late in 1941, and that's where I was in December of 1941, the United States got directly involved in the war situation.
I spent practically the entire war period as an officer in submarines one way or another.
I take it from such things as silver and bronze stars in World War II that you were, in effect, the line officer all during the war, not involved in any of the research like Revell and these people.
No, I was not involved in oceanographic research.
In fact, most of the people that I knew at that stage in the game who had not been in ROTC, my colleagues in ROTC,
and the physics department had all gone off to places like Oak Ridge and Los Alamos.
And so I really knew, by implication, more about what was going on there than I did about oceanography.
I learned the hard way about underwater acoustics and things of that sort because we had sonar systems, very primitive ones, in the beginning on onboard submarines.

I learned also about internal waves in the ocean and things like this just by the fact that periodic buoyancy changes in your submarine if you were operating close to the surface were things that you had to cope with.
But I had no intention at that point of becoming an oceanographer per se.
Late in the war, as things were winding down,
I had the opportunity of going off to Harvard as part of a Navy postgraduate thing.
And in fact, the war ended while I was at Harvard, or just as I went to Harvard.
And so I had a choice of either staying in the Navy or finishing off that one-year graduate course still in the Navy and then going back to an active status.
And I elected to finish the course.
At that point I chose to go back to Berkeley, which I did in 1946, back to the physics department and to work toward a doctor's degree.
So you worked really towards...
I was involved in basic physics still at that point, and the group with which I became involved was in fact
under Professor Emilio Segre, who eventually got the Nobel Prize, but not until after I left.
And that was high energy nuclear physics.
And of course, that's what that physics department was famous for.
But it was also a very good department in that it was very strong on classical physics as well as in those days, as well as in high grade research in the nuclear side of the game.
And when I finished my degree, I had been active in the, I had stayed active in the Submarine Naval Reserve.
I was the commander of a naval reserve unit in the San Francisco Bay Area during that period.
And so when I finished off my degree, I was kind of tempted to do something that would combine the nuclear physics and the submarine.
And so I

Most of the places that I visited in the inevitable job hunting period that comes right at the end of the degree, several of them anyway, were places that were involved in the then very new nuclear power business, which was solely tied up with some new sorts of things.
And I wound up
just because of this sort of coalition between the submarine interest and the physics interest.
And while I was there, I hadn't been there even a year, and came out for a visit back to San Francisco area, which is where I was born.
And at that point,
I got a call from a friend of mine with whom I had worked as a graduate student.
He was still a graduate student, just about to finish off.
And he had been approached by Scripps to come down here and talk about a possible job in marine physics.
This fellow had an army background.
It happened that he knew one of the people who was helping to search for somebody to fill a vacancy.
And so he told the people who were talking to him that I was around and that I was a physicist, but I was much more interested in the ocean than he was, and that they should ask me to come down.
So they asked both of us to come.
came on down and turned out that one of the members of the Marine Physical Laboratory was about to go off for a year.
He had been running sort of a very nice program in underwater acoustics that was of considerable interest to the Navy and sponsored by the Office of Naval Research.
And they wanted a physicist who could carry this on

while he was away, and they were looking toward expanding the size of the laboratory somewhat anyway, so they were recruiting, and they made an offer to both Thompson, who was the other fellow with me, who eventually became an Atomic Energy Commissioner, and died tragically in an airplane crash while he was doing an inspection, site inspection thing over in Nevada.

But anyway, they offered me a job and I really, the contrast with the Knowles Atomic Power Laboratory where there were a couple thousand people working on sort of building one very sophisticated engine and this sort of thing where I could come and have a little research group and see the whole program in my hand and control it and do something that was directly, that interacted directly with the ocean.
It was at that point that I clearly made the move that I never regretted at all.
It was a very good thing, just personally.
So I came here and started doing underwater acoustics and sonar system sorts of things.

This was again a good, it built well on my background because I could take the good classical physics that I had worked hard on at Berkeley and combine it with the submarineing that I had been doing because it turned out that a lot of us underwent acoustics at that stage in the game.
In order to have quiet platforms from which to do acoustic measurements, we did a lot by working with the submarine force
local in here.
We would go out on the submarine and huddle and do some propagation tests and things of this kind.
And so the fact that I could argue with a submarine commanding officer helped me a great deal in being able to make this sort of thing go.
I have several questions I'd like to ask for 46 to 51.
Did you do organized submarine research while you were attending Berkeley?
You have an abbreviation there.
It's Organized Submarine RES, which stands for Reserve.
I ran a Navy Organized Submarine Reserve training
unit in that area throughout that period.
Helped to write the training programs and things like this because it was a completely new sort of enterprise.
There had never been a submarine component to the Naval Reserve until after World War II.
And so I did that in parallel with
the work toward the PhD in nuclear physics.
Okay, and your work in nuclear physics was really in what direction?
What kind of research were you doing in Berkeley?
I was working on, well the thesis had to do with, actually that's been a long time, I was working with the
by then sort of intermediate energy cyclotron in the Crocker laboratory there that had a power range up to 23 muv and doing studies of heavy elements
bombarding them with particles and looking to see what kinds of reactions would result, particularly things around aluminum and lead and this sort of business.
There were some interesting short-half-lived alpha emitters that had not been studied.
It was that sort of thing that unraveled a few odds and ends, and that became a thesis.
Were you involved with the Atomic Energy Commission at this time?
Only in that I held an Atomic Energy Commission
fellowship for one of the years that I was working on the doctor's degree.
Of course, at the North Atomic Power Laboratory, that was an organization that was in fact funded by the Atomic Energy Commission.
Okay, now, when you become director of NPL, were you able then to guide the research activities of the lab?
Well, directing a laboratory isn't
I had built up my own research in underwater acoustics and marine geophysics and basically this laboratory, it's a small one, we had a handful of very talented people
And the main function of the director was to see that the life went reasonably smoothly for them and to get out of their way at the right times.
And at the same time, since it's a small laboratory, I was able to keep my own research going.
And this has worked out pretty well over the long haul.
I had been here at the laboratory about six years before I became director.
We had had two previous directors who were both, I think, quite influential in my life.

One of them was the man who basically recruited me to come here in the first place, Carl Eckhart, who was a distinguished physicist, who had become involved in the University of California Division for Research during World War II, and played a major role in that organization.
And then he had been
figure in theoretical matters and quantum mechanics and thermodynamics and things of this kind.

When he came out here during the war he became quite interested in the ocean and in particular in a sort of missionary sense I guess because he was a very fine person in his ability to see how to apply high-grade mathematical methods to problems that other people hadn't yet applied them to.

and he did this during the war in the sonar and acoustics business and when the war ended he decided he really didn't want to go back to the University of Chicago and so he convinced the navy that they should set up a laboratory within the University of California because he didn't really want to stay in the navy civil service laboratory situation which was what in fact the University of California Division of War Research
at the end of the war, was kind of mostly turned into an organization called the Navy Electronics Laboratory.
Descendants of that still exist here on the planet today.
And at the same time, he arranged that the Marine Physical Laboratory should be established within the University of California.
It was not really a part of Scripps' institution of oceanography.
It was just an entity within the university with Eckhart as its director.

part of the reason he was able to do this, and was encouraged to do it, was that one of the people with whom they were dealing in Washington, in the Navy Bureau of Ships, in the sonar design branch, was a commander named Roger Revell, who was on leave from Scripps, and so he was at the other end of this sort of thing, and within that framework, it had been decided they would go ahead and do this thing

establishing a small laboratory that the Navy would fund, which would focus on problems in underwater acoustics and similar concepts, but which would be somewhat different from the in-house Navy laboratories which were then growing up, which would be rather more engineering oriented, but this would be more basic science oriented.
And so that was basically the way this sort of thing started.
Eckart, in 1948, became director of scripts for a while.
After a 20 minute hiatus, Eckart did become director of scripts at that point.
decided that there was no reason that there should be a small laboratory, the Marine Physical Laboratory in the San Diego area and the rather larger Scripps Institution, and so he
decided to make the Marine Physical Laboratory de facto a division of the Scripps Institution.
And the laboratory has maintained that position ever since.
In fact, I guess it's the oldest existing administrative subdivision of the institution.
And that explains how you could be director of MPL and also associate director of Scripps Institution of Oceanography?
Well, that goes another way too in that
Eckhart moved from being director of MPL to being, for a brief time, the director of Scripps because Sverdrup left in a fairly sudden manner.
And so Eckhart kind of held the place together while they girded themselves up to recruit Roger Revelle to be the director of Scripps.
And as you know, Revelle was the director for some considerable length of time.

in 19, must have been late 61, something like that, Ravel, now this is a sort of trick situation, Ravel had been heavily involved in the development of the new campus here, the full-scale University of California campus.
And in about 1961, they
things had developed to the point at which they were going to appoint a chancellor for the campus and the decision was made not to appoint Ravel.

He obviously was disappointed as were many of the rest of us who had worked with him because he had been sort of using Scripps or Scripps had used itself to help with the overall development of the campus and a lot of us felt we had a lot at stake and we were not
really all that pleased when this happened, but nevertheless it did, and so it must have been the fall of 61.
Roger decided that since the Chancellor had been appointed, Herb York, who was a perfectly good man, a very good man, Roger accepted
a position as science advisor to the head of the Department of Interior, I guess it was.
In fact, I think he was the first of the departmental science advisors.
And so he went off to Washington.

And what he left behind him was essentially a complex of three jobs, chief campus officer, the head of what was then the School of Science and Engineering, which was the beginning of the general campus here, and the directorship of the Scripps Institution.
And I was asked, at that point, to take on the directorship of the Scripps Institution, which I did, much in the same vein as Eckhart, before me, had stepped from the Marine Physical Laboratory.

And I'm not sure whether it's because my office is off the campus and all the other people at Scripps are on the campus, and maybe the Marine Physical Laboratory director, therefore, is thought to be a little more neutral and, therefore, more acceptable in this.
context anyway.
He, Roger left and I took over as the director for a period of close to two years.

It was a particularly interesting thing if you're interested in coincidences and that sort of business in the history of science because the three of us who wound up taking the three parts of Ravel's job
had all been graduate students together in the physics department at Berkeley simultaneously.
Herb York and I were in the same research group.
We both did our degrees for Segre.
Keith Bruckner, who was a theoretical physicist who was head of the School of Science and Engineering at that point, he and I had been teaching assistants together in courses around 1950 at Berkeley.
And we'd all three arrived by completely different

I guess in a sense the only one who arrived really legitimately was Berkner because he stuck with the physics business and came to, eventually came to UCSD to head up the physics department and then took over as head of the school of science and engineering when Roger left.
Herb York had gone the route of
administration and so forth, having gone to ARPA and the Defense Research and Engineering Establishment in Washington before coming here.

He, in fact, had been involved in things of that kind even at Berkeley when he was quite young, because he was, I can remember, he was sort of in charge of scheduling and things of this kind on the cyclotrons, while I was still a graduate student at Berkeley.

probably right by the most illegitimate means, because I had, in fact, just plain abandoned physics, more or less, and although up till that point, I guess I still, we can talk about when did I become interested in oceanography or something like that.
When the manpower questionnaires come by, you write in, they always want you to say whether you're a physicist or whatever, and
I had been putting down physicist or geophysicist every year until I got to be director of Scripps.
And I figured there was no way I could honorably do that anymore.
So at that point I decided I was in oceanography.
I'd been around Scripps for about nine years at that point.
And I think that in much of oceanography this is the way, certainly in those years, this was the way it went.
That people came in.
usually on an opportunistic basis, which mine certainly was.
I didn't come in because I went looking for a job in oceanography.
The job came looking for me.
Once I saw it, I didn't hesitate very long.
But nevertheless, that's the way oceanography did develop in that sort of ten-year period.
And I think that's one of the places where Ravel was very good, that he had tentacles out and could bring in interesting people to populate this growing institution that we had.

do it in such a way that the people who would come mostly came initially with the idea that whatever the particular discipline was in which they were involved was probably capable of solving most of the problems of oceanography or something of this kind, or at least they weren't necessarily initially interdisciplinary people.
By the time they'd been around for a few years, you began to interact with the other people in the group and eventually you got to where a lot of us are pretty strongly interdisciplinary oriented.
We can work with people who have completely different philosophies about how to do one experiment, the last.
A half dozen of my graduate students have been marine geologists, and they just don't think the way physicists do.

But I've learned that there are many ways of thinking about science, and that geologists' ways are sometimes the right way to attack a problem, particularly if it's a problem in the real world as opposed to a laboratory-type problem.
physicists have brought up with a sort of laboratory orientation.
This is really not the only one that one should have if one is going to study the ocean.
When you become associate director of Scripps Institution, what sort of...
This was not...
I was the director of Scripps Institution at that point.
That was in 1961 to 1963.
Then Ravel came back from Washington and took over again as director of Scripps.
And I went back to being...

I had retained the directorship of the Marine Physical Laboratory during this period, and I became also, at that point, moved over to being chairman of the Department of Oceanography, as well as the director of FDL.
Revelle then left for good, about, when was that, 64 or 65, I mean, there someplace,
He was back for the order of a year, year and a half.
And then he went off to Harvard.
And that was a permanent dissociation.
And again, I took over the directorship of Scripps for about a year, during which time we made a search for a permanent director.
And the end result was recruiting Bill Nirenberg to be the director.
And he started in 1965, I guess.
And it was at that point that he asked me to be one of the associate directors.
I guess partly just out of politeness or whatever, because I've been in the front office for so long, but in any event, this has continued.
It's a kind of associate directorship that sometimes has lots of action associated with it and other times has none.
It's kind of a special assistant type
thing as opposed to some of the other associate directors of scripts who have specific spheres in which they act.
Bob Fisher, for example, who is associate director for facilities, particularly for ships and that sort of thing.
So that was pretty much how that sort of thing developed.
I think that the institution certainly has
hasn't changed all that much, I don't think.

Some people would say it's changed a lot, I guess, but I think it's, in that it's grown, it's become a little more difficult to recognize explicitly the interdisciplinary things and the sort of oneness of the place.
When I first came, we had Wednesday,
lunches and everybody, a fair number of the members of the staff would come and bring their sack lunch and somebody would talk about whatever was interesting to them.
That's the kind of thing that has gone away.
I think this is in part due to the growth of the general campus itself as well as the growth of the institution.
Testing, one, two, three, testing.
Testing, one, two, three, testing.
Testing, one, two, three, testing.
